instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the models for vegetation-impervious-soil (VIS) mapping across multiple cities and how far can this metric go in terms of accuracy?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the models in the related study was the average mean absolute error (AV-MAE). This metric measures the average absolute difference between the predicted and actual values of the vegetation-impervious-soil (VIS) fractions. 

In terms of accuracy, the AV-MAE provides a measure of the overall error in the predictions. The lower the AV-MAE, the more accurate the model is considered to be. 

In the study, the AV-MAEs for the generalized model ranged from 8.5% to 12.2% for the known sites (Berlin, Brussels, and Santa Barbara). The performance of the generalized model was very similar to the local models, with Delta AV-MAEs falling within a range of +/- 0.7%. 

For the unknown sites (San Francisco Bay Area and Munich), the AV-MAEs for vegetation and impervious fractions using the generalized model were 5.4% and 10.9% respectively for the San Francisco Bay Area, and 6.3% and 15.4% respectively for Munich. 

Overall, the AV-MAE metric provides a quantitative measure of the accuracy of the models in predicting VIS fractions.

instruction: How were the single regression models spatially generalized for vegetation-impervious-soil (VIS) mapping across multiple cities in the related study?
Output: In the related study, the single regression models for vegetation-impervious-soil (VIS) mapping across multiple cities were spatially generalized by combining support vector regression (SVR) with synthetically mixed training data generated from spectral libraries. Three local models were developed based on separate spectral libraries from Berlin, Brussels, and Santa Barbara. Additionally, a generalized model was created based on a combined multi-site spectral library. This approach allowed for the transferability of the models throughout different cities and enabled the mapping of VIS fractions across multiple locations.

instruction: Can the combination of SVR and synthetically mixed training data generated from multi-site libraries be considered a superior approach for generalized urban mapping across multiple cities, compared to traditional methods?
Output:
Yes.Based on the information provided in the related study, the combination of support vector regression (SVR) and synthetically mixed training data generated from multi-site libraries can be considered a superior approach for generalized urban mapping across multiple cities compared to traditional methods. 

The study used this approach to develop a generalized model for vegetation-impervious-soil (VIS) mapping across multiple cities. The performance of the generalized model was compared to local models based on separate spectral libraries from specific cities. 

The results showed that the generalized model was capable of accurately mapping VIS fractions across all three known sites (Berlin, Brussels, and Santa Barbara). The average mean absolute errors (AV-MAEs) for the generalized model were very similar to the local models, with Delta AV-MAEs falling within a range of +/- 0.7%. This indicates that the generalized model performed as well as the local models in terms of accuracy.

Furthermore, when the models were transferred to two unknown sites (San Francisco Bay Area and Munich), the generalized model proved to be useful for mapping vegetation and impervious fractions. The mean absolute errors (MAEs) for both cover types were comparable to or better than the local models for these unknown sites.
